Description: Mould-made pottery plastic handle broken from the rear of a lamp, decorated with Isis (lactans) enthroned, suckling Horus (Harpocrates). Part of an adjacent, separately moulded and applied figure survives, perhaps Sarapis. At the rear is part of a ribbed handle, applied to join the the two figures. Covered with an orange-brown slip. Red Nile silt fabric with common mica and while inclusions.
Curator's comments: Part of an adjacent, separately moulded and applied figure survives, perhaps Serapis in the Benaki Collection (MP779). See also parallel in British Museum (Bailey 1988, Q2007, EA49651, EA1875,0517.71). However other parallels, including an example from Canopus have similar Isis figures combined with a figure of Isis-Demeter (Tran Tam Tinh 1973, pl.62, 157; Breccia 1928, pl.36,2) found on other Egyptian mould decorated lamps in the British Museum (Bailey 1988, Q2009-Q2010). Breccia, E. 1928. La Rovine e i Monumenti di Canopo. Bergamo. Tran Tam Tinh, V. 1973. 'Isis Lactans. Corpus des monuments gréco-romains d 'Isis allaitant Harpocrate'. EPRO 37. Leiden. Walters, H.B. 1914. Catalogue of the Greek and roman lamps in the British Museum. London.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q.08)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.16) (Phase 1)
